elements.title: Problem-First Discovery Outreach Card - Category-Defining Three-Tier Sequence
elements.description: Kelly rejected Split Lease because Bryant led with the solution (Landon's schedule) instead of the problem (unprotected direct hosting). This three-tier card enforces Play Bigger's 'market the problem, not the solution' principle through visual hierarchy: a warm amber Problem tier dominates, the purple Category tier resolves it, and a quiet Proof tier presents the guest match. The progressive visual weight ensures the host absorbs the risk question before encountering any solution data, preventing the instant category-rejection that occurred on Kelly's call.
elements.html_css_snippet:
SplitLease Discovery

For property owners in Troy, MI

Your current exposure

Guaranteed-Income Hosting
You get paid whether the guest stays or not. Every guest is verified before they ever see your property. If anything goes wrong, we handle resolution.

Landon M. Verified professional · Mon–Fri · 3 months starting Feb Income guaranteed from day one

elements.title: Risk-Contrast Comparison Card - Category Displacement Through Side-by-Side Risk Dimensions
elements.description: Kelly evaluated her hosting approach on a single dimension (trust through direct vetting) and never considered payment risk, damage liability, or early departure exposure. Play Bigger teaches that category kings sell 'different, not better.' This comparison card frames direct hosting and guaranteed-income hosting as categorically different along risk dimensions, not feature dimensions. The amber risk column carries more visual weight than the purple protection column, ensuring the host absorbs the problem before the solution -- mirroring the Birdseye frozen food ad strategy of making the old category seem incomplete.
elements.html_css_snippet:
What happens when things go wrong?

Comparing your risk exposure across two approaches

Guaranteed-income

Tenant leaves early
You lose income and begin a new search
Income guaranteed through the full lease term

Direct hosting gives you control. Guaranteed-income hosting gives you control and protection.

elements.title: Vetting Evidence Trail - Inspectable Trust Cards for Control-Oriented Hosts
elements.description: Kelly's core objection was about information depth and personal control: 'I wanted someone who I can get a little bit more information as far as their nursing and just being more confident in who they were.' This component answers her exact question with verifiable evidence organized into expandable cards. Play Bigger's Choice Supportive Bias says Kelly will rationalize direct vetting as superior -- unless the platform's evidence is undeniably more comprehensive. Each card uses document-style formatting with source attribution and dates, creating the feeling of 'I am evaluating this myself' rather than 'someone else approved this for me.' Purple verification badges replace the style guide's no-green rule.

elements.title: Guaranteed-Income Proposal Card - Host-Controlled Approval with Equal-Weight Actions
elements.description: Kelly's identity is built on control: 'I'd prefer to just kind of work with individuals directly.' Play Bigger's magic triangle requires product/category fit -- and for control-oriented hosts, the product must feel like 'I decide,' not 'they decided for me.' This proposal card presents lease terms with the host as the explicit decision-maker. Approve and Decline buttons are equally weighted visually, signaling genuine evaluation rather than rubber-stamping. The guaranteed income amount is prominently displayed as the category-defining detail, reframing the proposal from 'here is a tenant' to 'here is your guaranteed income.' All terms are editable, preserving agency.

You decide. No obligation, no penalty for declining.

elements.title: Post-Rejection Category Seed Card - Minimal Anchor for Long-Term Recall
elements.description: Kelly left the door open: 'If anything changes or I have an associate that has a property, I will definitely give you.' Play Bigger's 6-10 law shows categories take years to establish. This minimal seed card is sent via SMS 25 minutes after a declined call to replace the wrong category anchor ('matchmaker') with the right one ('guaranteed-income hosting'). Its extreme restraint -- one bold purple headline, two lines of definition, one risk scenario, one personal contact -- ensures the host glances at it once and remembers the category name for months. No CTA, no features, no signup link. The warm close leverages the Michigan connection Bryant and Kelly shared.
elements.html_css_snippet:
Guaranteed-Income Hosting

You get paid whether the guest stays or not.
Every guest is verified before they see your property.

If a tenant stops paying

You still get paid through the full lease term. If they leave early, your income continues. If there is damage, we handle resolution.

Bryant

Your hosting protection manager · Troy, MI

(248) 555-0100

elements.title: Local Social Proof Notification - Geo-Anchored Community Update for Pre-Category Hosts
elements.description: Play Bigger's Groupthink Bias research shows that 'when we hold an opinion that differs from others in a group, our brains produce an error signal.' Kelly volunteered her Troy, MI identity and mentioned associates with properties -- she is socially embedded in a local hosting network. This notification, triggered only by real geographic adoption milestones, activates belonging rather than FOMO. The large purple count number is the visual focal point, triggering the brain's error signal: 'other property owners near me are doing this.' No CTA, no pitch -- pure informational social proof delivered as a neighborhood update, not platform marketing.
elements.html_css_snippet:
Troy, MI

Guaranteed-income hosting update

3 property owners now use guaranteed-income hosting

$12,400 in guaranteed income paid to Troy hosts this month

Bryant is still your hosting protection manager if you ever want to learn more.

elements.title: Category Vocabulary Reference - Strike-Through to Replacement Internal Guide
elements.description: Bryant described himself as 'a matchmaker between guests and hosts' -- vocabulary that instantly categorized Split Lease as an intermediary within Kelly's existing mental model. Play Bigger's Jawbone case study shows that even great products fail when vocabulary maps to the existing category. This internal reference card systematically replaces every intermediation term with category-defining vocabulary. Old labels appear faded with strike-through (visually expired), while new labels appear in bold purple (visually authoritative). Agents consult this during calls. The visual pattern makes the vocabulary shift feel like a paradigm replacement, not a word swap.
elements.html_css_snippet:

elements.title: Guaranteed Income Dashboard - Active Lease Overview with Payment Certainty
elements.description: Play Bigger's flywheel concept shows that category kings accumulate advantages through data and network effects. For hosts who convert, the active lease experience must reinforce the category choice daily -- proving that guaranteed-income hosting delivers on its promise. This dashboard centers the guaranteed payment amount as the dominant visual element (the category-defining value), with lease progress, next payment date, and guest status as supporting data. Every element reinforces 'you are getting paid regardless' -- the category promise that Kelly never heard. For control-oriented hosts, all actions remain host-initiated: they can message the guest, review terms, or request changes, maintaining the agency that makes adoption sustainable.
